Our partners at Lionakis share progress on the new Harder Elementary School. Click below to view more photos and read more about the project.

"Harder Elementary School, a new replacement campus in Hayward, is edging closer to completion and will soon join its sister school, Cherryland Elementary School, as the two newest schools in the Hayward Unified School District. Both elementary schools celebrate their communities and pull design inspiration from the area, as well as the history of the schools. The Harder campus design is abstract and celebrates the long time mascot of the campus, the Hawk. At this point in construction, throughout the campus you will see the swooping roofs that mimic a hawk in flight, as well as a light color palette. The welcoming campus design pulls much of its inspiration from the hawk’s lowland and mountainous habitat."
#madeinhayward
#thankyouhayward

Richard Valle
August 4 at 4:20 PM ·

This morning Alameda County Probation Department, Hayward Unified School District and District 2 Office came together to celebrate Ms. Davida Scott and her Raising Leaders Program. At today’s Board of Supervisors meeting $190,636.40 from District 2’s Enhancing Vision 2026 Fund and $422,229 from the Probation Department was approved to continue and expand the great work Ms. Davida is leading. Raising Leaders is a workshop and internship model created to give at-risk youth an opportunity to hear from leaders within the community and gain hands-on paid work experience. Raising Leaders is all about having faith in yourself and your potential, Ms. Davida Scott brings out the best qualities in every young person she meets. Congratulations on your tremendous achievements. Thank you Ms. Davida for your inspiring work and Alameda County Chief Probation Officer Wendy Still for supporting programs that provide opportunities to our youth.

"Ever since I can remember, I wanted to be a registered nurse. My interaction with my school nurse at a Catholic elementary school made a great impact on me. I learned a lot from her! When I graduated from Nursing school, I had the dream become a reality. I wanted to help my community and families. I am bilingual and I have been able to work in clinical nursing in my community, where I went to school, working with teens, peds and family health. I became a school nurse almost 9 1/2 yrs ago. I hope that I can share the same care that has touched me and to pass it on to the students and families that I work with." -Exia Sikes

HUSD wants to remind you that you can help prevent the spread of germs by:

(If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.)
-Avoiding close contact with people who are sick
-Avoiding touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
-Keeping children home when they are sick
-Covering your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throwing the tissue in the trash.
-Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe.

You can find updated information and resources about the coronavirus and how to prevent the spread of illness by visiting www.husd.us/coronavirus

The City of Hayward and the Hayward Adult School partnered together and created Raising Leaders in Hayward-Workshops & Internships with the goal of giving students in alternative education programs( i.e. Adult Schools, Continuation High Schools, Teen Moms , Independent Studies and students on expulsion) the chance to learn and gain experience in various fields by offering professional development opportunities through the City of Hayward, District 2 partnerships, and California State University, East Bay. Our vision is to offer disadvantaged Hayward youth custom-tailored workshops designed to teach them life skills while simultaneously preparing the next generation of workforce members in our community.

Students and staff at both organizations joined forces to present at the California Workforce Association' s Youth@Work 2020 Conference.

Congratulations to longtime HUSD music teacher Mark Schmidt on receiving the CA Music Educators Association, Bay Section’s 2020 Outstanding Music Educator Award.

Mark Schmidt attended the University of Redlands, where he received a Bachelor of Music degree in Trumpet Performance, as well as his teaching credential. He later attended Holy Names University in Oakland, where he received his Masters of Music degree, with an emphasis in Kodaly methodology.

He taught for 34 years in the #HaywardUnifiedSchoolDistrict until he retired in June of 2019. He taught a Kodaly-based curriculum to students in Grade 1-4 and conducted a 5th and 6th grade choir at Southgate Elementary School. Mark's classroom instruction was always well sequenced and provided a lot of fun for the students.

Congratulations, Mr. Schmidt. Hayward Unified is proud to have music teachers like Mark Schmidt. #Music #MadeinHayward #artseducation #teachersrock

Performances that evening will include the Mt. Eden High School Choir, the Cherryland Elementary School Drama Club and members of the Chabot College Forensics Team delivering speeches on civil rights and social justice themes.

The Dr. King Birthday Celebration began in Hayward in 1986. In 1993, the event Planning Committee began honoring individuals who have contributed substantially to keeping Dr. King’s work and spirit alive in Hayward—a tradition that will continue next month.

College courses for HUSD middle school and high school students? Yes!

Now enrolling! The 2020 YEP Bridge to College courses are set to begin January 27, 2020, at Bret Harte, Chavez, King, Ochoa and Winton middle schools and Hayward High School, Mt. Eden and Tennyson high schools. Students can enroll in college-level courses taught by Chabot College instructors, including Drama, Sociology, Anthropology, Ethnic Studies, and Sign Language.

This is the only program of its kind in California, which offers college courses on our own secondary school campuses, directly after school. Congressman Eric Swalwell
November 6, 2019 at 1:05 PM ·

Congrats to Jordan Robinson of Hayward Unified School District’s Mt. Eden High School, who took the stage at San Francisco’s Orpheum Theatre last month to perform his slam poetry as part of the Hamilton Education Program.

The #eduham program is a national partnership giving public school students the chance to see Hamilton performed live and integrate the show into classroom studies. Before the students see the show, they’re introduced tothe people, events, and documents of the Founding Fathers’ era. Students also learn how Lin-Manuel Miranda, the show’s creator, incorporated primary sources into the songs he wrote for the show and use that knowledge to produce their own performance pieces. Some students are selected to perform their own works onstage before seeing a matinee of the show.

Jordan performed his poem on the life and significance of Benjamin Banneker, a free African-American almanac author, surveyor, naturalist, and farmer who helped survey the original borders of the District of Columbia. Watch, learn… and rise up!
